15.body: Your task is to create an instance of the player class. Hint: something = ClassName() Doing so will call the __init__(self, ...) method of the class. Now, thinking back to yesterday, how might we access the variables of this class?
15.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » GAME BASICS » Create an instance of player » Task 2.2: Create an instance of player
15.title: Task 2.2: Create an instance of player

16.body: Under the player method, we need to create a draw method(). How might we create a method inside a class? If you are stuck have a read here . Perhaps the screen.blit(...) function could be useful... Now, in order for the player position to be updated very often, where would we call this draw method?

17.body: Your task is to create the move method.
17.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » GAME BASICS » Create the move method » Task 2.4: Create the move method
17.title: Task 2.4: Create the move method

18.body:
First, you need to find whether a certain key is being pressed or not. Similar to yesterday, we can use a function called pygame.key.get_pressed() . Hint: This returns a list of booleans.
For example, the return value may look something like this -> [False, False, False, False, True, False, False] How might we check whether the 7th key is pressed?
18.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » GAME BASICS » Create the move method » Task 2.4.1
18.title: Task 2.4.1

19.body:
Secondly, we need to update the position_x and position_y variables of our player according to what key was pressed. For example, something like if w is pressed move up
else if a is pressed move left
else if s is pressed move down
else move right

19.title: Task 2.4.2

21.body: We’re going to fix the trailing images issue by re-drawing the background to the screen every time the game loops. Draw the background to the screen again inside the game loop before drawing the bird. That fixed it!

28.body: Goal: Detect whether the player is colliding with any of the food.
28.title: Task 4 Collision

29.body:
Create an extra property in the player and food class. Use the .get_rect().move() function to create a rectangle that moves with the class' sprite. Create a method called update(self) in the player class. Copy the property you just wrote into this method. Call the player update method in the main game loop, just underneath player.draw() # sprite.get_rect() creates a rectangle the size of the image
# .move() moves whatever it's attached to to an x and y coordinate
self.hitbox = self.sprite.get_rect().move(self.position_x, self.position_y)
29.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » COLLISION » Creating hitboxes » Task 4.1 Create a hitbox for both the players and the foods
29.title: Task 4.1 Create a hitbox for both the players and the foods

3.breadcrumbs: SET UP » Import Pygame » Import Pygame
3.title: Import Pygame

30.body:
Create a property called interact_foods(self, food) in the food class Use the colliderect to check whether the rectangular hitboxes are colliding If they are colliding, remove food from the active_foods list # Collision is True is the hitboxes are colliding and False if not
collision = self.hitbox.colliderect(food.hitbox)
30.breadcrumbs: NEW GAME » COLLISION » Detecting collision » Task 4.1 Create a hitbox for both the players and the foods
30.title: Task 4.1 Create a hitbox for both the players and the foods
